awd_titl_txt: A Research-Practice Partnership for Developing Computational Thinking through Linguistically and Culturally Relevant CS Curriculum in Middle School
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), together with El Paso Independent School District (EPISD), will develop a research-practice partnership (RPP) to plan and pilot a linguistically and culturally relevant computer science curriculum in middle school with the goal of broadening the participation of emergent bilingual (or English learner) students and Latino/a students in computer science (CS) education. The project will focus on the development of an RPP that can effectively help teachers use bilingual and culturally relevant tools to develop the computational thinking (CT) skills of middle school students in EPISD. By bringing together the promise of culturally relevant CS education and of dual language instruction, this project will seek an innovative solution to the problem of underrepresentation of Latinas/os and emergent bilingual students/English learners in CS education and careers. It does so through a research-practice partnership that ensures responsiveness to the needs of educational practitioners and facilitates the integration of prior NSF-funded research with existing classroom curriculum and practice. The project, together with future scaling work, potentially can serve as a model in at least two existing large networks-the NSF-funded National CAHSI INCLUDES Alliance and the New Tech Network-strengthening efforts in both to broaden participation and engagement of underrepresented students, with particular focus on CS. Through dissemination across the 60 CAHSI institutions, the proposed linguistically and culturally relevant approach could potentially contribute to broadening Hispanic and emergent bilingual participation much beyond the El Paso region. The curriculum developed collaboratively by the RPP would also be disseminated through the national New Tech Network repository of PBL curriculum, accessible to other NTN schools across the country. The model of integrating culturally responsive CT/CS instruction and linguistically responsive dual language instruction has potential to significantly advance efforts to reach, support, and engage more Hispanic youth in CS learning and careers.

The project builds upon research showing that culturally relevant CS education is a promising approach to broadening participation of minoritized students in CS and that dual language bilingual education is a successful approach to improving participation and academic achievement of emergent bilingual (or English learner) students by taking a culturally and linguistically relevant approach to CT/CS instruction for emergent bilingual and Latina/o students. Specifically, the project develops an RPP to plan, co-design, pilot, and refine a curriculum module that is bilingual (Spanish and English) and employs an existing NSF-funded culturally-relevant game-based learning platform, Sol y Agua (Akbar, et al., 2018), that uses locally familiar El Paso area geography and ecology to teach computational thinking. The project will address the following research questions: (1) In what ways and to what extent do teachers demonstrate understanding of computational thinking principles and components and of dual language principles and instructional strategies? (2) How do teachers implement a linguistically and culturally relevant PBL module using Sol y Agua game-based learning platform? And (3) In what ways and to what extent do students demonstrate learning of computational thinking principles and components during and after participating in a linguistically and culturally relevant PBL module using Sol Y Agua? The project will deploy a range of data collection including pre-post testing of teachers' knowledge and implementation of instruction, observation, video recordings of classrooms, and student written assessments and language tracking data from the software tool Sol y Agua. The research team will analyze the data using qualitative data analysis techniques as well as data mining and classification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We are part of a national effort to inspire more students from minority backgrounds to explore careers in STEM fields, with a particular emphasis on essential computer skills. Our team at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) joined forces with the El Paso Independent School District (EPISD) to create a unique curriculum tailored to the distinct culture and language of our border region students.

Our goal was to introduce the concept of "computational thinking" (CT) to two middle schools, but we didn't just use any ordinary curriculum. We harnessed the power of a bilingual and culturally-sensitive game called "Sol y Agua" to make learning an engaging experience. In this paper, we'll walk you through our journey and share what we've uncovered so far.

As we dug into the game data, something fascinating emerged: students frequently switched between English and Spanish while playing, underscoring the importance of educational tools that resonate with students through their language and cultural familiarity.

Additionally, when we examined feedback from teachers and team members, we found that these educators grasped the concepts of computational thinking and translanguaging. They understood how these ideas could be applied in both academic subjects and everyday life. However, integrating these concepts consistently into their teaching materials and methods posed a challenge.

In simpler terms, our project's mission is to ignite the enthusiasm of minority students for STEM and computer skills by crafting a curriculum that respects their culture and language. The data indicates that students thrive in an environment that mirrors their culture and language, yet teachers sometimes encounter difficulties in integrating these concepts seamlessly into their teaching materials and methods.

In the realm of education and technology, there's a well-recognized issue: not enough Latinx students are venturing into computer and STEM fields. 

 To help convey these concepts effectively, we leveraged a computer game known as "Sol y Agua." This study unfolded in two EPISD middle schools, where this specialized curriculum was implemented across three different subjects: math, social studies, and English language arts. Five dedicated teachers collaborated to develop and test this curriculum, involving a total of 138 students.

 So, what did we uncover? Well, the data gleaned from the game and curriculum testing yielded intriguing insights. However, the pivotal takeaway is that this partnership and the curriculum they fashioned hold immense potential to kindle Latinx students' interest and involvement in technology and STEM fields. The crux of the matter lies in creating opportunities and connections that render learning more captivating and relevant for these students.

Now, let's delve into our research regarding how teachers and students acquire and utilize two vital elements: computational thinking (CT) and translanguaging. This endeavor is part of a larger initiative where teachers and researchers mutually learn and grow.

 Throughout this study, teachers absorbed the essence of CT and its applicability across diverse subjects and real-life situations. For instance, Mr. V, one of the teachers, harnessed CT to teach math, concentrating on step-by-step problem-solving. Meanwhile, Mr. D employed it in English, illustrating persuasive writing.

An intriguing facet of this journey is that many teachers realized CT is already an integral part of their daily lives, akin to finding more efficient routes in traffic – they simply didn't recognize it by name. Similarly, they comprehended the concept of translanguaging, the practice of using multiple languages in teaching, even though they often weren't explicitly aware they were doing it.

When it came to imparting CT and translanguaging, teachers did so, albeit at times implicitly. This means they didn't always overtly mention that they were teaching these skills. For instance, Mr. V taught algorithmic thinking in math, yet didn't employ the term "algorithm" to describe it. The debate revolved around whether to explicitly teach these skills or maintain an implicit approach, considering the aim of preparing students for computer science.

 Within classrooms, teachers often transitioned seamlessly between English and Spanish, incorporating translanguaging naturally. However, these transitions weren't always planned and were occasionally absent from lesson plans. On a few occasions, students were explicitly tasked with creating bilingual projects, but in most cases, bilingual usage occurred spontaneously.

So, what about the students? Well, they practiced CT and employed their bilingual skills without always discussing them explicitly. In some instances, they weren't even cognizant that they were employing CT until they engaged with the Sol y Agua game. Moreover, they made use of translanguaging, such as when they watched a video in English with Spanish subtitles and discussed it in both languages to tackle problems.

In a nutshell, this research underscores that teachers and students are actively engaging with CT and translanguaging, even if it's not always explicitly acknowledged. It's a natural aspect of their learning process, and our study contributes to understanding how it unfolds and how it can be enhanced moving forward.
